files.patch:
@@ -266,1 +266,1 @@ -| [Fixed]{.jbs-value} | [Resolved]{.jbs-value} / [Closed]{.jbs-value} | The [Fixed]{.jbs-value} resolution should be used **only** if a change has been integrated in a repo to address the issue. For the JDK project in almost all cases the bots will transition the issue to [Resolved]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value} when the changeset is pushed to the repo. An issue in [Resolved]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value} state needs to go through [verification](#verifying-an-issue) to end up as [Closed]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value}.
If there isn't a fix in the repo (and so no associated changeset) then the issue should not be marked as [Fixed]{.jbs-field}, but rather set to [Delivered]{.jbs-field}. | +| [Fixed]{.jbs-value} | [Resolved]{.jbs-value} / [Closed]{.jbs-value} | The [Fixed]{.jbs-value} resolution should be used **only** if a change has been integrated in a repo to address the issue. For the JDK project in almost all cases the bots will transition the issue to [Resolved]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value} when the changeset is pushed to the repo. An issue in [Resolved]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value} state needs to go through [verification](#verifying-an-issue) to end up as [Closed]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value}.
If there isn't a fix in the repo (and so no associated changeset) then the issue should not be marked as [Fixed]{.jbs-field}. | @@ -278,1 +278,1 @@ -| [Delivered]{.jbs-value} | [Resolved]{.jbs-value} / [Closed]{.jbs-value} | Used to close out issues where a change to the code isn't required, common examples are Release Notes and umbrella issues for larger projects. | +| [Delivered]{.jbs-value} | [Resolved]{.jbs-value} / [Closed]{.jbs-value} | Used to close out issues where a change to the code isn't required, common examples are Tasks, Release Notes, and umbrella issues for larger projects. |
